title: Titles of the people of God

children.title: believers
children.comment: Those who have faith in God. After Pentecost, the term came to be used specifically to refer to Christians, that is, to those who believe and trust in God, as he has made himself known through Jesus Christ. The NT stresses that Jesus Christ brings the faith of OT believers to perfection and to its proper fulfilment.

cschildren.title: Believers as those who have faith in God
OT believers looked forward to the NT faith
The church is referred to as the believers
In the early church a distinction was sometimes made between Jewish and Gentile believers
The term believer is synonymous with Christian
Believers are members of God's family

children.title: body of Christ
children.comment: The term refers both to the physical body of Jesus Christ, which was broken on the cross in order that redemption might be accomplished through him, and to the church.

cschildren.title: The body of Christ symbolised in the Lord's Supper
The church as the body of Christ

children.title: Believers as members of the body of Christ
Jesus Christ as the head of the body
Jesus Christ's resurrection body is a new temple

cschildren.title: Life in the body of Christ

children.title: Baptism is into the body of Christ
Believers receive spiritual life through the body of Christ
Believers care for each other in the body of Christ
Believers have different gifts in the body of Christ
children of God
children.comment: Israel and the church are the chief objects of God's fatherly love. People become God's children through faith and are then encouraged by Scripture to imitate their heavenly Father in their daily living.

primaryrefs.comment: These words referred originally to David's son, Solomon, but in the NT they are applied to Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ's followers as God's children
Becoming God's children through faith in Jesus Christ

children.title: Becoming God's children by new birth

seealsos.comment: This adoption will be fully realised in the future

children.title: Becoming God's children by the Spirit
God does not abandon his children

primaryrefs.comment: God had previously (Hos 1:9) announced his judgment that Israel would be his people no longer.

children.title: God's children imitate their heavenly Father
God's children live by the Father's standards

cschildren.title: The privileges and blessings of being God's children

children.title: The needs of God's children are always supplied

seealsos.comment: promises for the life to come

children.title: God's children have a sure inheritance
Christians
children.comment: Those who belong to Jesus Christ; other designations in Scripture are believers, disciples and the children of God. Originally a nickname, the term is only used three times in the Bible.

children.title: Christians described as children of God
Christians described as heirs of God
Christians described as members of God's household
Christians described as the people of God
elect, the
children.comment: Those chosen by God, entirely of his grace, for the special privilege of experiencing salvation.

cschildren.title: Individuals chosen by God as his elect
God's elect enjoy his presence and favour

children.title: The elect are asssured of the presence of God
The elect are assured of the protection of God
The elect are assured of a place in the world to come
The elect are assured of justice
flock, God's
children.comment: God's people are frequently portrayed as a flock of sheep, for whom he cares with the tenderness and concern of a loving shepherd.

children.title: Jesus Christ portrayed as a shepherd
Israel and Judah depicted as God's flock
NT believers depicted as God's flock
Many of Israel's leaders exploited God's flock
God will judge the corrupt shepherds
Church leaders are to care for God's flock
Israel, as the people of God
children.comment: God called Israel out of Egypt to be his own treasured possession and his covenant faithfulness with them is maintained, despite their persistent disobedience.

children.title: The nation was founded upon God's promises to the patriarchs
God enters into a special covenant relationship with Israel
Israel's privileged status within the covenant
Israel provoked God in the wilderness
Israel's unfaithfulness in the promised land
God's promise not to abandon Israel completely

seealsos.comment: Though Israel will be destroyed, a holy remnant will be left

children.title: God's promise to bring Israel back to the land
The promise of a restored relationship between Israel and God

cschildren.title: Jesus Christ, the Saviour of Israel

children.title: Jesus Christ's ministry was specifically to the nation of Israel
Jesus accepts the title ``Christ'' (Messiah), God's anointed deliverer for Israel

primaryrefs.comment: Although Jesus accepted the title ``Messiah'' (Christ), he did not fulfil contemporary Israelite hopes of a political deliverer.

children.title: Jesus Christ declares to Israel the good news of God's reign

primaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ takes up Isaiah's message of good news, that God is coming in sovereign power to restore Israel (see Isa 40:9-10, 52:7).

children.title: Israel warned that rejection of Christ means exclusion from the kingdom
Membership of the true Israel is based on God's election, not merely on physical descent from Abraham
A remnant of Israel has been elected by grace
Paul declares that ``all Israel'' will be saved

secondaryrefs.comment: The phrase ``all Israel'' is interpreted as either: (1) the total number of the elect (either Jews, or Jews and Gentiles) of every generation, or (2) the great majority of Jews of the final generation who will be saved when Christ returns.

children.title: The church as the new Israel
The church described as the 12 tribes of Israel

seealsos.comment: Some see this as a reference to members of actual Jewish tribes, but others see it as symbolic of all the faithful believers who live through the time of tribulation
The number 12 emphasises the continuity of the NT church and the OT people of God.

children.title: The apostles as the 12 leaders of the new Israel
people of God
children.comment: Those called out to belong to God and serve him in his world.  God called Israel to be his people in the OT, anticicpating the calling of the church in the NT.

children.title: people of God, in OT
children.comment: The OT relates how God called Israel to be his people.

children.title: people of God, in NT
children.comment: The NT relates how the Christian church is the new people of God, assuming all the privileges and responsibilities of Israel in the OT, but with a universal mission to all the world, rather than any one nation.

children.title: Believers are the true children of Abraham
The church is the people of God
Jesus Christ sends believers into all the world
people of God, in OT
children.comment: The OT relates how God called Israel to be his people.

children.title: people of God, in NT
children.comment: The NT relates how the Christian church is the new people of God, assuming all the privileges and responsibilities of Israel in the OT, but with a universal mission to all the world, rather than any one nation.

children.title: Believers are the true children of Abraham
The church is the people of God
Jesus Christ sends believers into all the world
remnant
children.comment: A small group of people who remain faithful to God, despite widespread unbelief or faithlessness around them. God preserves a remnant in order to ensure a renewed and restored people in the future.

cschildren.title: God preserves a remnant of his people

children.title: Joseph and the sons of Israel
Survivors of Assyria's invasion of Judah
Survivors of the destruction of Israel
children.precomment: People from the northern kingdom of Israel who had moved to Judah and so escaped its destruction by Assyria:

children.title: Judah as the remnant of God's people
Survivors of the fall of Jerusalem
children.precomment: Those taken as exiles into Babylon:

children.title: Those who returned after the exile
Those waiting for Jesus Christ's coming

cschildren.title: The remnant as the few who escape judgment
God's promise of hope and restoration

children.title: Hope for a remnant seen in the coming of the Messiah
God's promise that survivors will remain
The land restored to the remnant of God's people

cschildren.title: Further promises associated with the remnant

children.title: God's promise of forgiveness to the remnant

cschildren.title: The remnant as heirs of God's new covenant

secondaryrefs.comment: The promise of the new covenant is made to the surviving remnant of Israel

children.title: A faithful remnant among the Jews
A faithful remnant from among the Gentiles

secondaryrefs.comment: Jesus Christ's other sheep are believing Gentiles who will be gathered with the believers of Israel

children.title: God's new Israel includes all believers

cschildren.title: Other references to a surviving remnant
cschildren.precomment: Og, king of Bashan, only survivor of the Rephaites:

secondaryrefs.comment: survivors from the tribe of Benjamin
the scattered remains of Israel's army under Ahab

children.title: righteous, the
children.comment: The designation, especially in the OT, of those who live and act in accordance with God's commands.

cschildren.title: The equality, in human terms, of the righteous and the wicked

children.title: saints
children.comment: The people of God, especially in relation to their being set apart from the world to serve him. Believers are called upon to lead holy lives worthy of their calling.

cschildren.title: Saints are set apart for God

primaryrefs.comment: To be holy is to be set apart.  The same Greek word is used in the NT for both ``holy'' and, in the plural, ``saints''.

children.title: They are members of God's covenant people

cschildren.title: Saints are to live lives worthy of their calling
Saints have responsibility for one another
Saints have spiritual union with Jesus Christ
Saints are precious in God's sight

children.title: servants of the Lord
children.comment: A description of individuals, groups, and the nation of Israel. Isaiah portrays a unique servant whom the NT identifies as Jesus Christ.

cschildren.title: Individuals as servants of the Lord

children.title: The patriarchs as servants of the Lord
Moses as the servant of the Lord
Other leaders as servants of the Lord
David as the servant of the Lord
Other kings as servants of the Lord
Individual prophets as servants of the Lord
Paul as the servant of the Lord
Other individual believers as servants of the Lord
Pagan kings as servants of the Lord

cschildren.title: Groups of servants of the Lord

children.title: The people of Israel as the Lord's servants
Failure of the people of Israel to serve the Lord
Other nations as the Lord's servants

cschildren.title: The Lord's servants recognised as such by pagans
The unique servant of the Lord

children.title: Jesus Christ's life identifies him as the Lord's servant
NT leaders proclaim Jesus Christ as the Lord's servant
Serving the Lord as he requires

cschildren.title: The Lord's care for his servants
The reward of the Lord's servants
